note.p: Birth: Spring Grove (Brightwater), New Zealand (30 August 1871)
Death: Cambridge, Cambridgeshire, England (19 October 1937)
Burial: Westminster Abbey, London (ashes)
Research Field: Physics, chemistry

Education: Nelson College, New Zealand (Marlborough Education Board Scholarship) (1887-1889); Canterbury College, Christchuch (1890-1894). BA, BSc, MA (Hons), DSc (University of New Zealand); BA (Cambridge); BSc (McGill, ad eudem)

Career: Worked as a relieving teacher, Christchurch Boys High School (1894); won a scholarship as a research student in England and went to work with J J Thompson (FRS 1884), Cavendish Laboratory, Cambridge; Professor, McGill University, Montreal, Canada (1898); worked on radioactivity with Frederick Soddy (FRS 1910); moved to Manchester University, England (1907); worked on acoustic detection of submarines (during World War 1); Director, Cavendish Laboratory, Cambridge, where he split the atom (1919); helped to found, and was President of, the Academic Assistance Council to aid displaced academics (1933); received about 32 Honorary doctorates; his honours included 34 medals, and Honorary Fellowships of many societies; his picture appeared on $100 (NZ) note (went into circulation 1992) Had little patience with left wing politics or with theoretical speculation generally. His accent was said to be a combination of West Country and Cockney.
Honours: Kt 1914; OM 1925; Baron 1931
Memberships: Hon RSNZ (1904); FInstP (president 1931-1933)
Membership: Fellow
Election Date: 11/06/1903
Medals/Prizes: Rumford Medal 1904; Copley Medal 1922; Nobel Prize (Chemistry) 1908
Lectures: Bakerian 1904 and 1920
